{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox building | name = Robert and Anne Dickey House | image = Elizabeth Berger Plaza 35 - Behind the Scaffolding.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Looking from Trinity Place | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = | building_type = | architectural_style = [[Federal architecture|Federal]] | classification = | location = 67 [[Greenwich Street]]
[[Financial District, Manhattan]], New York | coordinates = {{coord|40.707188|-74.013685|format=dms}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = 1809 | stop_date = | topped_out_date = | completion_date = 1810 | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | client = | owner = | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | material = | size = | floor_count = 4 | floor_area = | elevator_count = | architect = | architecture_firm = | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = NYC | designation1_date = June 28, 2005 | designation1_number = }} | references = {{cite web|title=ROBERT and ANNE DICKEY HOUSE, 67 Greenwich Street (aka 28-30 Trinity Place), Manhattan. Built 1809-10.|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/dickeyhouse.pdf|website=nyc.gov|publisher=[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]]|accessdate=June 28, 2017|date=June 28, 2005}}{{cite web|title=Endangered Buildings Initiative: 67 Greenwich St.|url=http://www.nylandmarks.org/programs_services/endangered_buildings_initiative/67_greenwich_st/|publisher=[[New York Landmarks Conservancy]]|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} }} The '''Robert and Anne Dickey House''', also referred to as the '''Robert Dickey House'''{{cite news|last1=Dunlap|first1=David W.|title=Hidden Corners of Lower Manhattan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/travel/hidden-corners-of-lower-manhattan.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 15, 1991}} or by its address '''67 Greenwich Street''', is a [[Federal architecture|Federal]]-style building in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of Manhattan in New York City. The site is bounded by Edgar Street to the south, [[Greenwich Street]] to the west, and [[Church Street (Manhattan)|Trinity Place]] to the east. It is named after Robert Dickey, a 19th-century New York merchant, and his wife Anne, who both resided in the house. Erected circa 1810, it is one of the few remaining Federal-style buildings in the city, and was designated a New York City Landmark in 2005. Currently in disrepair, the building is slated for renovation and conversion into a school as part of the construction of the adjacent [[77 Greenwich Street]]. ==Description== The Dickey House is located at the south end of a block bounded by Edgar Street to the south, [[Greenwich Street]] to the west, and [[Trinity Place]] to the east, with Rector Street at the north end of the block.{{cite web|title=ROBERT AND ANNE DICKEY HOUSE: 67 GREENWICH STREET|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/presentation-materials/02_16_16/67%20Greenwich%20Street.pdf|website=[[Government of New York City|nyc.gov]]|publisher=Trinity Place Holdings, [[FXFOWLE]],|accessdate=January 30, 2018|date=February 16, 2016}} Adjacent to the north of the building was a former [[Syms Corporation]] store, demolished in 2017. This is the site of the future [[77 Greenwich Street]] tower. Located to the south across Edgar Street is [[Elizabeth H. Berger Plaza]]. Also immediately to the south are the approaches to the [[Brooklyn–Battery Tunnel]]. The building was designed by an unknown architect in [[Federal architecture]] style. The design has been erroneously attributed to [[Pierre Charles L'Enfant]]. As originally constructed the house was 3 {{frac|1|2}} stories tall, with the top {{frac|1|2}} story occupied by a [[gable|peaked]] roof. An 1872 alteration by architect [[Detlef Lienau]] replaced the peaked roof with a fourth story capped by a flat roof with a metal [[cornice]]. The front face of the building on Greenwich Street is flat and four-windows wide. The bottom floor is utilized for retail space. The rear face of the building on Trinity Street is five bays wide. It features an "[[elliptical]]" or "[[Bow and arrow|bow]]-shaped" facade, which occupies the northernmost three windows and extends outward towards the street. This was an original design feature, and the 1872 remodeling maintained this element for the fourth floor.{{cite landmarks|page=95}} The elliptical design has been compared to that of buildings in [[Boston]]. The ellipse originally faced a garden on the property. The south facade on Edgar Street contains a chimney and no windows. It was originally adjacent to another building, until that building was demolished and Edgar Street was relocated north to front the building during the construction of the Battery Tunnel in the 1940s.{{cite book|author1=Barbara Rizek|author2=Martin Rizek|author3=Joanne Medvecky|title=The Financial District's Lost Neighborhood: 1900-1970|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VP7NMO878sEC&pg=PA2|accessdate=January 30, 2018|year=2004|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-3511-1|pages=2, 12–13, 20}} Windows may have existed on this face in the past. The south face was later used as a billboard. The outer facade of the house consists of red brick, but the front (Greenwich) and rear (Trinity) faces have been painted gray. A one-story "commercial addition" was constructed in 1922 on the Trinity Place side of the building. This addition was most recently used as a [[tavern]]. As of 2011, the Dickey House is one of only seven surviving pre-1810 houses located south of [[Chambers Street (Manhattan)|Chambers Street]]. The building, however, has been in disrepair since the turn of the 21st century. Currently, the house is hollowed out, with its roof and chimney removed to facilitate construction of 77 Greenwich (see below). Only three outer faces (Greenwich, Edgar, Trinity) currently make up the building.{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Michael|title=Excavation Begins For FXFOWLE-Designed 77 Greenwich Street, Financial District|url=https://newyorkyimby.com/2017/10/excavation-begins-for-fxfowle-designed-77-greenwich-street-financial-district.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=New York Yimby|date=October 20, 2017}} Numerous historical landmarks are located in the vicinity of the house. To the west and north at Greenwich and Rector Streets is [[88 Greenwich Street]]. One block north of the site on Trinity Place are the [[Trinity Church (Manhattan)|Trinity Church]] and the [[American Stock Exchange Building]]. To the immediate southwest across the Battery Tunnel approaches is [[21 West Street]].{{Cite NYCS map|neighborhood|Lower Manhattan}} ===Rehabilitation=== As part of the construction of 77 Greenwich Street, the Dickey House will be renovated and converted for use as a public elementary school building. The school will occupy both the house and portions of the lower floors of the tower. The exterior will be restored to its 19th-century condition. The 1922-built retail addition, considered non-historical, will be removed to create a new entrance to the building. Part of the new tower will [[cantilever]] over the house. The project was designed by [[FXFOWLE]]. The house will be renovated by the [[New York City School Construction Authority]].{{cite news|last1=Weiss|first1=Lois|title=Trinity Place complex gets a new look — and a new name|url=https://nypost.com/2016/01/27/trinity-place-complex-gets-a-new-look-and-a-new-name/|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[New York Post]]|date=January 27, 2016}} ===Transportation=== The Dickey House is directly served by several [[New York City Subway]] stops. The [[Rector Street (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)|Rector Street]] station of the [[IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line]] ({{NYCS trains|Broadway-Seventh South Ferry}}) is located under Greenwich Street, and a [[Rector Street (BMT Broadway Line)|station of the same name]] is located on the [[BMT Broadway Line]] ({{NYCS trains|Broadway south}}) under Trinity Place. The [[Wall Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Wall Street]] and [[Bowling Green (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Bowling Green]] stations of the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]] ({{NYCS trains|Lexington south}}) are located under Broadway east of the site. The {{NYC bus link|M55}} local bus serves the site on Trinity Place (northbound) and Broadway (southbound). Numerous [[List of express bus routes in New York City|express bus routes]] to/from outer boroughs also operate in the area.{{Cite NYC bus map|M}} The [[Staten Island Ferry Whitehall Terminal]] is located south of the site, connected by the subway or bus. ==History== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | image1 = Mrs. Robert Dickey (Anne Brown) MET DP205027.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Robert Dickey MET ap69.22.1.jpg | caption2 = | width = 150 | footer = Paintings of Anne Dickey (left) and Robert Dickey circa 1810, by [[John Wesley Jarvis]] | footer_align = left }} Robert Dickey and Anne Dickey (née Brown) were both born in what is now [[Northern Ireland]], and later emigrated to the United States. Robert Dickey arrived in the U.S. in 1798. The two married in [[Baltimore]], Maryland in 1807.{{cite book|author=Tunis Garret Bergen|title=Genealogies of the State of New York: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of a Commonwealth and the Founding of a Nation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wekpAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA522|accessdate=January 30, 2018|year=1915|publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company|pages=522–}}{{cite book|author1=John Caldwell|author2=Oswaldo Rodriguez Roque|author3=Dale T. Johnson|title=American Paintings in The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Vol. 1: A Catalogue of Works by Artists Born by 1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dYdWBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA296|accessdate=January 30, 2018|date=March 1, 1994|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|pages=296–299|id=GGKEY:5A107H6P5DU}}{{cite book|title=Biographical Sketches of the Leading Men of Chicago|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oltKAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA429|accessdate=January 30, 2018|year=1868|publisher=Wilson & St. Clair|pages=429–}}{{cite book|author=John Crosby Brown|title=A hundred years of merchant banking: a history of Brown Brothers and Company, Brown, Shipley & Company and the allied firms. Alexander Brown and Sons, Baltimore; William and James Brown and Company, Liverpool; John A. Brown and Company, Browns and Bowen, Brown Brothers and Company, Philadelphia; Brown Brothers and Company, Boston|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PC0vAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA329|accessdate=January 30, 2018|year=1909|publisher=Priv. Print.|pages=329–}} Robert Dickey was a spice merchant, whose fortunes put him among the wealthiest men in New York City at the time. The lower ends of Greenwich Street and Trinity Place were created circa 1790, when a "[[beach ridge|bluff]]" created by the [[Hudson River]] tides was leveled and filled in order to be developed. In 1809, Robert Dickey purchased three lots at the south end of Greenwich Street. Two of the lots were originally owned by [[Comfort Sands]] and given to his daughters in 1796. One of his daughters was the wife of New York banker and broker [[Nathaniel Prime]]. Dickey proceeded to construct two houses on the site, addressed 69 and 71 Greenwich Street (later 65 and 67). Stables and a storehouse fronting Trinity Place (then called Lumber Street) were also built on adjacent lots.{{cite news|title=House 67 Greenwich Street|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%25201831-1832%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%25201831-1832%2520-%25200577.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D66148b25%26DocId%3D7177115%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D2b4a%2B2b4b%2B2b4c%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%25201831-1832%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Advertiser%25201831-1832%2520-%25200577.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D66148b25%26DocId%3D7177115%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D2b4a%2B2b4b%2B2b4c%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[New York Daily Advertiser]]|agency=[[Fultonhistory.com]]|date=January 23, 1823}} At the time Greenwich Street was known as "Millionaire's Row" and later called the "Original [[Park Avenue]]", and the two houses were among numerous other Federal-style rowhouses on the street. Dickey acquired the adjacent 73 Greenwich Street (future 69 Greenwich) in 1816, while selling 69 Greenwich. He operated his business ventures from the rear of the property on Lumber Street. In 1821, Dickey sold the two remaining houses. In 1822, the [[New York City Common Council]] established the modern building addresses on Greenwich Street; 71 Greenwich Street was renamed 67 Greenwich Street. [[File:(King1893NYC) pg695 BIRD'S-EYE VIEW FROM THE WASHINGTON BUILDING; LOOKING NORTHWEST.jpg|thumb|right|The [[IRT Ninth Avenue Line|Ninth Avenue]] (left) and [[IRT Sixth Avenue Line|Sixth Avenue]] (right) elevated lines merging near the Dickey House circa 1893]] The house was transferred to Peter Schermerhorn (brother of [[Abraham Schermerhorn]]) in 1823, and the Schermerhorn family owned the building through the 19th century. During this time, the house was rented out to prominent New Yorkers. These included [[William Bayard Jr.]], [[Nicholas Low]], and Ezra Ludlow (father of [[William H. Ludlow]]). It also served as the [[Consulate General of France in New York|French Consulate]] building from 1830 to 1831. By the 1840s, it became a [[boarding house]]. In the late 1860s, construction began on the [[IRT Ninth Avenue Line|Ninth Avenue Elevated]] railroad along Greenwich Street in front of the house. The elevated line opened in 1868. Shortly afterwards, the [[IRT Sixth Avenue Line|Sixth Avenue Line]] was erected along Trinity Place (then called New Church Street), with the two lines merging at Morris Street. This meant that both the front and rear faces of the Dickey House were obstructed by elevated tracks.{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Christopher|title=Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; A Statue of Joan of Arc, and a Curved Facade|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/06/realestate/streetscapes-readers-questions-a-statue-of-joan-of-arc-and-a-curved-facade.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 6, 2003}} In April 1871, the house was among several in Lower Manhattan raided by police under the suspicion of prostitution.{{cite news|title=BREAKING UP THE BAGNIOS.; Twenty-nine Houses of Ill-Fame Suppressed in the First Ward Thirty Men and Ninety-two Women Incarcerated in the Tombs.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1871/04/09/archives/breaking-up-the-bagnios-twentynine-houses-of-illfame-suppressed-in.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 8, 1871}} In 1872, [[Detlef Lienau]] was contracted to remodel the house, removing the hipped roof and adding the building's fourth floor. By this time, the building was used as a [[tenement]], with the original upper class residents of the neighborhood having relocated uptown and immigrants taking their place. An 1890 police census reported 57 tenants of Irish descent occupying the house. The house was sold in 1919 to Rose A. McGuigan.{{cite news|title=Old Trow Printing Plant To Be Used for Business|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201919%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201919%252010-22%2520Page%252019.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D33d70b35%26DocId%3D5148678%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3Da85%2Ba86%2Ba87%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201919%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201919%252010-22%2520Page%252019.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D33d70b35%26DocId%3D5148678%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3Da85%2Ba86%2Ba87%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[New-York Tribune]]|agency=[[Fultonhistory.com]]|date=October 22, 1919|page=19}} One year later, McGuigan (also spelled "McGuigman") filed plans to convert the house and the adjacent 65 Greenwich Street property into a six-story office building.{{cite news|title=Plans Filed for Big "Village" "Show House: 2,332-Seated Theater Will Cover Block and Will Cost $400,000 to Build|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201920%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201920%252003-25%2520Page%252019.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe5aa1cbc%26DocId%3D5419579%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D4aa%2B4ab%2B4ac%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201920%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Tribune%2520%25201920%252003-25%2520Page%252019.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe5aa1cbc%26DocId%3D5419579%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D4aa%2B4ab%2B4ac%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[New-York Tribune]]|agency=[[Fultonhistory.com]]|date=March 25, 1920|page=19}} Around this time, the surrounding neighborhood west of Greenwich Street developed into an Arab immigrant community known as [[Little Syria, Manhattan|Little Syria]].{{cite news|last1=Parsons|first1=Walter B.|title=SYRIAN BUSINESS SECTION CHANGING|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1920/03/21/archives/syrian-business-section-changing-notable-improvements-being-made-in.html|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 21, 1920}} In 1922, the one-story shop extension was constructed on Trinity Place. [[File:Historic American Buildings Survey (Fed.), Stanley P. Mixon, Photographer Mar. 23, 1940, (K) EXT. VIEW OF REAR BAY FROM TRINITY STREET. - Greenwich Street Study (Plot plan), New HABS NY,31-NEYO,54-11.tif|The Dickey House looking from Trinity Place in 1940. Note the adjacent buildings on both sides, and the one-story shops in front of the house.|thumb|left]] The Sixth and Ninth Avenue elevated lines were closed in 1938 and 1940 respectively, and dismantled in the 1940s.{{cite news|title=6th Ave. 'L' to Shut Down At Midnight Tomorrow|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1938/12/03/archives/6th-ave-l-to-shut-down-at-midnight-tomorrow-city-will-formally-take.html|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 3, 1938}}{{cite news|work=[[New York Times]]|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0A14FF345D10728DDDAB0994DE405B8088F1D3 |title=Two 'El' Lines End Transit Service|date=June 12, 1940|page=27}} During the construction of the [[Brooklyn–Battery Tunnel]] in that decade, numerous buildings in the neighborhood were demolished. This included many on Greenwich Street, and most of Little Syria. The Dickey House, however, remained, with Edgar Street moved north to the south face of the house.{{cite news|last1=Amateau|first1=Albert|title=13 Federal-style buildings are eyed as landmarks|url=http://thevillager.com/villager_16/13federalstyle.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The Villager (Manhattan)]]|date=August 20, 2003}}{{cite news|last1=Skidmore|first1=Howard F.|title=Battery Tunnel Maw Swallowing Citrus Original Park Avenue: Oldest Neighborhood, Once ihe Best, Laler a Polyglot Village, Awaits Wreckers|work=[[New York Herald Tribune]]|agency=[[ProQuest]], [[New York Public Library]]|date=April 14, 1946|page=A11}} Because of this, the house would later be described as a "[[Robert Moses]] survivor".{{cite journal|title=LANDMARKS PRESERVATION COMMISSION: Owners challenge designation|journal=[[Center for New York City Law|CityLand]]|date=May 15, 2005|volume=2|issue=4|pages=60-61|url=http://archive.citylaw.org/cityland/wp-content/uploads/sites/39/cityland/2005/May/Hr5N87rC.pdf|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} In 1960, the Dickey House was purchased by brothers-in-law Irving Schachter and Eli Goldhagen. At this time, the building was used by a paper company. The house was first nominated for possible landmark status in 1967. On February 11, 1991, the [[State historic preservation office|New York State Historic Preservation Office]] identified the building as a potential [[New York State Historic Sites|state]] or [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Manhattan|national landmark]].{{cite book|author=Allee King Rosen and Fleming, Inc.|title=Route 9A Reconstruction Project: Final Environmental Impact Statement; Appendix C: Cultural Resources|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N641AQAAMAAJ&pg=SL3-PA10-IA1&lpg=SL3-PA10-IA1&dq=%22triborough+bridge+and+tunnel+authority%22+%22battery+place%22&source=bl&ots=3SCF2kWGEI&sig=FPnpj2MzefwBQSLjMDW_UfqV0oM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiaz9r-0PbZAhVKwlkKHZwJC1AQ6AEIYjAG#v=onepage&q=%22triborough%20bridge%20and%20tunnel%20authority%22%20%22battery%20place%22&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2018|date=May 1994|publisher=[[New York State Department of Transportation]], [[Federal Highway Administration]], [[United States Department of Transportation]]|pages=C-20−C-21}} By the turn of the 21st century, the house was in a state of disrepair. Following the [[September 11 attacks]], the building was vacated. On June 28, 2005, the house was designated as a city landmark by the [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]]. The designation was opposed by Martha Schachter Schessel and Harry Schessel, who were the owners of the house and the descendants of Irving Schachter. They wanted the building to be demolished.{{cite news|title=After 38 years, Greenwich St. building is finally landmarked|url=http://thevillager.com/villager_114/after38years.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The Villager (Manhattan)]]|date=July 6, 2005}}{{cite news|last1=Dunlap|first1=David W.|title=Downtown, Federal Era Blooms In Hiding|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/20/arts/downtown-federal-era-blooms-in-hiding.html|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 20, 2003}}{{cite news|last1=Satow|first1=Julie|title=Downtown Home Could Be Given Landmark Status|url=http://www.nysun.com/new-york/downtown-home-could-be-given-landmark-status/3394/|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[The New York Sun]]|date=October 19, 2004}} The family claimed restoration costs would run to $6 million. ===Redevelopment=== In 2008, it was revealed that the [[Syms Corporation]], who owned and operated a store in the adjacent building (42 Trinity Place), planned to develop a multi-story tower on the shop site. To do this, they would need to purchase [[air rights]] from adjacent buildings including the Dickey House.{{cite news|last1=Covert|first1=James|title=Flagship Makeover|url=https://nypost.com/2008/04/29/flagship-makeover/|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 29, 2008}} In May 2008, Syms purchased the Dickey House.{{cite news|last1=Chatelain|first1=Ryan|title=10 historic New York buildings now eyesores|url=https://www.amny.com/10-historic-new-york-buildings-now-eyesores-1.883914|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[AM New York]]|date=July 17, 2008}} In November 2011, Syms filed for bankruptcy and closed all of its locations in January 2012.{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Ashley|last2=Dominguez|first2=Robert|title=Syms and Filene’s Basement file for bankruptcy and will close all stores by January|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/money/discount-retailers-syms-filene-basement-file-bankruptcy-close-stores-january-article-1.971141|accessdate=January 30, 2018|work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=November 2, 2011}} Beginning in late 2014, Syms (now reorganized as Trinity Place Holdings) planned to construct a residential and retail tower on the former store.{{cite news|last1=Dailey|first1=Jessica|title=Trinity Place Development Site Could Sprout This Tower|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2014/12/17/10010872/trinity-place-development-site-could-sprout-this-tower|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=[[Curbed]]|date=December 17, 2014}} By 2016, the project was named 77 Greenwich Street. The plan would incorporate the Dickey House into the development, renovating the house for use as an elementary school. Demolition of the Syms building was complete in October 2017. At this time, the chimney and north face of 67 Greenwich were removed, and metal support beams were installed to maintain the house's structural integrity. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Robert and Anne Dickey House}} [[Category:Residential buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 1810]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Federal architecture in New York City]]

''[[Open Exchange (CNBC)|Open Exchange]]''
2003–2015:
''[[Power Lunch]]'' | related = | website = https://www.cnbc.com/street-signs-asia }} '''''Street Signs''''' is a television business program that originally aired on [[CNBC]], and currently airs on [[CNBC Asia]] and [[CNBC Europe]]. Before the Asian version debuted on March 31, 2014 (see "CNBC Asia" further down this page for more information), it was broadcast on [[CNBC]] at 2:00pm ET. The CNBC United States version's final episode aired on February 6, 2015, due to ''Power Lunch'' returning to a two-hour format. The European version of ''Street Signs'', which is aired in a one-hour format on [[CNBC Europe]], debuted January 4, 2016 (see "CNBC Europe" further down this page for more information). ==List of ''Street Signs'' anchors== ===CNBC US=== *Maria Bartiromo (2pm ET, 1999–2002) *Ron Insana (1996–2002 (3pm ET, 1999–2002); 2003–2006) *Erin Burnett (2006–2011) *Amanda Drury & Brian Sullivan (2011–2015) ===CNBC Asia=== *Oriel Morrison (2014–present) *Martin Soong (2014–present) ===CNBC Europe=== *Louisa Bojesen (2016–2017) *Carolin Roth (2016–present) ==About the show== This program focuses on the day's market action. In addition, prominent analysts, investors and executives regularly appear on the program to offer their perspective. ===CNBC=== [[Image:111807j.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The former set of ''Street Signs'' (2006-2010-04)]] ''Street Signs'' was originally a two-hour programme that aired on CNBC from 1996 to February 1, 2002. It was cancelled effective February 4, 2002 and ''Power Lunch'' occupied its vacated slot as a result of CNBC's revamped programming line-up. On December 8, 2003, former ''[[Business Center]]'' co-anchor and original host [[Ron Insana]] revived ''Street Signs''. And in March 2006, ''[[Squawk on the Street]]'' co-anchor [[Erin Burnett]] replaced Insana as the programme's new host. Burnett left CNBC on May 6, 2011. After Erin Burnett's departure [[Amanda Drury]] (late of CNBC Asia) and [[Brian Sullivan (news anchor)|Brian Sullivan]] (late of the Fox Business Network) became this program's new anchor team and were to be the show's final anchors. On October 13, 2014, ''Street Signs'' was launched in full 1080i high-definition as part of CNBC's network-wide switch to a full 16:9 letterbox presentation. One notable segment of the programme, which aired at 2:40pm ET, the "Stop Trading!" segment, was presented by [[Jim Cramer]] (host of another CNBC program, ''[[Mad Money]]''). In this segment, which formerly aired on ''[[Closing Bell]]'' prior to 2006-09-11, the co-anchors asked Cramer about the stocks making news, and also asked him for his take on the day's markets. After the segment, a full-screen disclaimer was shown as ''Street Signs'' go to a commercial break. Cramer's "Stop Trading!" segment was moved to the end of the first hour of ''Squawk on the Street'' on February 9, 2015. Jim Cramer's on-air tirade about the weakening economy, which was seen during the "Stop Trading!" segment of this program on 2007-08-03, garnered widespread attention and helped galvanise the [[Federal Reserve Board]] to cut [[interest rates]]. As of January 4, 2016, the European version of ''Street Signs'' is the only CNBC Europe program that is aired on CNBC's United States channel. Coincidentally (as previously mentioned), CNBC's own version of ''Street Signs'' aired its last show 11 months earlier, on February 6, 2015. ===CNBC Asia=== [[CNBC Asia]]'s version of ''Street Signs'' debuted March 31, 2014, with [[Martin Soong]] and [[Oriel Morrison]] as co-anchors. Soong was previously a longtime co-anchor of ''[[Asia Squawk Box]]'' and Morrison was anchor of the now-cancelled ''[[Cash Flow (CNBC Asia)|Cash Flow]]''. The background music for both the Asian and European versions is the same as CNBC Asia's ''[[The Rundown (CNBC Asia)|The Rundown]]'' and CNBC United States' ''[[Squawk Alley]]''. This programme originally aired in a two-hour format until October 29, 2018, when it was expanded to three hours (9:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m. SIN/HK) due to the cancellation of ''The Rundown''. ===CNBC Europe=== [[CNBC Europe]]'s version of ''Street Signs'' debuted January 4, 2016. Airing in a one-hour format from 10:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. CET, it replaced the first hour of ''[[Worldwide Exchange]]'', which itself had its airtime halved to one hour. However, the programme is occasionally extended to two hours on American bank holidays. The CNBC Europe version of ''Street Signs'' was originally co-anchored by [[Louisa Bojesen]] and [[Carolin Roth]]. Bojesen was previously anchor of the now-cancelled ''[[European Closing Bell]]'' and Roth, who became the solo anchor of ''Street Signs'' following Bojesen's departure from CNBC Europe on April 28, 2017, was previously co-anchor of ''Worldwide Exchange''. ''Street Signs'' is also broadcast on CNBC's United States channel from 4:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. ET. ==External links== *[https://www.cnbc.com/street-signs-asia/ ''Street Signs Asia'' official website on CNBC.com] *[https://www.cnbc.com/street-signs-europe/ ''Street Signs Europe'' official website on CNBC.com] *[https://www.cnbc.com/id/15837803/ ''Street Signs'' official blog on CNBC.com: ''Street Talk'' (since 2006-12-04)] {{CNBC Business Day}} {{CNBC Asia Business Day}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Street Signs (Tv program)}} [[Category:CNBC programs]] [[Category:CNBC Europe programmes]] [[Category:CNBC Asia programs]] [[Category:American television news programs]] [[Category:American television talk shows]] [[Category:1996 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2002 American television series endings]] [[Category:2003 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1990s American television series]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:Business-related television series]]

{{BLP sources|date=September 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Sun Guangxin | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1962 | birth_place = China | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Chinese | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = [[Urumqi]], China | education = | alma mater = [[Chinese Academy of Social Sciences]]
[[Tianjin University]] | occupation = Investor | known for = Founder, [[Guanghui Group]] | salary = | networth = [[United States dollar|$]]5.4 billion (November 2015){{cite web|title=Sun Guangxin|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sun-guangxin/|website=Forbes|accessdate=14 October 2015}} | spouse = | parents = | children = 2 | relatives = | website = }} '''Sun Guangxin''' (born 1962) is a Chinese businessman. ==Early life== Sun Guangxin was born in 1962. He received a Master of Arts from the [[Chinese Academy of Social Sciences]], and an EMBA from [[Tianjin University]]. ==Career== In 1989, Sun Guangxin founded Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group using 3,000 yuan from his decommissioning pay and 400,000 yuan from assorted bank loans.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Sun_Guangxin/bio|publisher=chinavitae.com|title=China Vitae : Biography of Sun Guangxin|accessdate=9 September 2016}} Today, this is a conglomerate with interests on energy, real estate and auto distribution. [[China Grand Auto]], which is controlled by Guanghui Group, is the largest auto dealer in China. ==Personal life== He is married with three children and lives in [[Urumqi]], China. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sun Guangxin}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chinese businesspeople]] [[Category:Chinese billionaires]] [[Category:Tianjin University alumni]] {{Business-bio-stub}}
